text: [Music]
it is an obsession isn't it this
Obsession of on happiness and uh there's
a historian Darren McMahon who wrote A a
wonderful book on the history of
Happiness it's one of my favorite books
on happiness and recently he said you
know only in America can this an
obsession with with happiness make you
unhappy and it's this you know you have
this feeling of there's perhaps there's
a little too much reflection on
happiness and I think there's a very
interesting philosophical Point
alongside that comment which is um does
this very
willful uh strategic Pursuit of
Happiness bring you happiness and we
don't know um the I think that the uh
Pursuit of Happiness is essential and
vital to our culture um it's guaranteed
in our constitution
the right to the pursuit of happiness
and we know from 250 studies in the
social and biological sciences that uh
as you cultivate happiness uh you become
healthier you become a better neighbor A
Better Community member you're more
productive and creative at work you're
stronger in your family with your
friends it's a good thing to go after um
and we're lucky that we can um but
everything has its excesses and I think
there's a the risk that uh it turns into
Naval gazing and the one thing that I
really felt in writing born to be good
is that we risk as our culture defining
happiness in terms of sensory Pleasures
wow this is a delicious wine uh or in
terms of exercise or in terms of
personal gratification and that's a
long-standing tradition in Western
thought that happiness is
economic gain and what I'm trying to
encourage is this more social Dimension
to happiness where you bring out the
good in others
